bibl.title: Gertrude Bell Diary extract (training data)
bibl.author: Gertrude Bell
bibl.note: Extract from GB-DIARY-11, pp.05-87. Transcription from original Gertrude Bell website, proofed by Evie Jeffrey. Created to train HTR models.

div.ab:
1909
Wed. Jan. 20. Left London at 11, Mother + Hugo seeing me off +
Willie T. appearing at the last moment. Travelled with out adventure
to Paris + dined +got into a full train.
Thurs. 21. My travelling companion was a Mrs Broadbridge, an
intelligent little woman wife of an engineer who is now on the W
coast of Africa, she had been all over the world. We talked
of the suffrage + I enlisted her among the Antis. Got to
Marseille at 9.30, bright but cold. My boat, the Equateus,
left at noon. Very empty; there are only 10 1st class male
passengers of various nationalities + an old French woman
of 70 who goes to Jerusalem every year for 2 months "pour
me distraire." I subsequently found that she was a cousin
of M. de Noailles. Pleasant afternoon but the wind got up
a little before eight + I went to bed soon after dinner.
Fri. 22. Fine morning. Read on deck. After lunch colder
+ some rain but little movement.
Sat. 23. On deck soon after 8, very fine but a cold wind.
Etna splendid, smoking half across heaven, + the snow
very low on all the hills. We saw the effects of the
earthquake as we passed through the straight. The
lamp of the big lighthouse all twisted, ruins
+ tents

in the upper parts of Scilla. Pezo half ruined. On the
other side all the houses from the lighthouse more or
less damaged. Messina looked from a distance undamaged
but one soon saw that the greater part of it was nothing
but a shell + when the facade of the front row of
houses was gone, a yawning gulf of ruins lay
revealed. At Reggio a railway line had fallen into the
sea, carriages in the water, the centre of the town a heap of ruins the sea
front just held up by long poles. Then suddenly all the
ruins ceased + we passed out into wind + a violent
hailstorm.
Sun. 24 Grey, cold, wind + an angry sea which got a
good deal worse after lunch + by dinner time a regular
gale. We had the fiddles on by team time. The worst night
I have ever known on the Mediterranean. I was not ill but
the noise + movement left me sleepless - a miserable
night.
Mon. 25. Better but still cold, grey + rough. By evening it
had quieted a little + I had my port open. Much warmer.
Tues. 26 Fine at last. The storm had delayed us + we did
not get to Alexandria till 3 though we were due at dawn.

I left most of my luggage on board + taking enough for 2
days, abandoned the ship with joy. Drove about Alexandria
+ went to the museum. A lot of Coptic things. 3 fine
large caps of basket work with a flower on each side -
6th C I should say. Some large Ionic cushion caps
possibly a little earlier. A good many ivories, the nymph
motive frequent but the Bacchus absent. A couple of
horrible Ledas in stone. A stone relief of St Menas
between the camels + a good many Ampullas. There
is besides an interesting headless porphyry statue of the
Roman period which must be compared with the one
at Cairo. Tea + leben in the town + so to the
station where I caught the 6 o'clock train + got to
Cairo at 9.15. Hotel d'Angleterre.
Wed 27 Did some shopping + || went to see Moritz. He
was just going out so I went to Ibn Tulun, photographed
the Mihrab caps, the 2 plaster plaques + the other
plaster decorations + so back to the library. Moritz told
me Sarre has done Resafa + showed me the Hatra book.
The only inscription seems to be Syriac - he says the
Parthian kings have Syriac names. There are some

interesting masons' marks, some appear to be Syriac letters
the others are Heaven knows what. In the absence of
inscriptions the place remains an enigma + must be
dug. We talked of the Hittites. He thinks the Mitani
empire lay between Tigris + Euphrates + never crossed
the latter. Sinjirli is Khatti. He spoke of Carchemish
as being at the junction of the Sajur + the Euphrates
+ that that must be the site. I showed him on Oppenheim's
map that it lay further north. He knows the site (
Jerabis? Jerablus) + says the town there must have
been small though he thought it was Carchemish. I begin
to doubt whether Mr H.'s site is not the true Carchemish.
Moritz advised me to go down E side of the Euphrates
from there as there are a number of towns to be identified
there + nothing has been done. || So there I shall go. I
saw + subsequently bought Oppenheim's publication of
his figures. They are near Ras el 'Ain. Note the remains
of a bridge over the Euphrates on what was the great
road from Carrhes to Hierapolis. The country through
which that track passes is probably not desert
though S. of it is desert. In the afternoon walked

into the native town past the Barkukich to the stone mosque
there. A stone plaque on the façade very closely resembles
Coptic wood work panels - what a jumble of motives
+ nationalities there is here! The mosque by the
(Edina)
gate I visited again. It also is very interesting. Some
fine Byz. caps in it. It is falling more + more into
ruin yet the stucco decoration round the arches is
splendid. So to Sultan Hassan which I vow they
have ruined by restoring. It consists now of acres of
stucco covering all the masonry indescribably
bare + horrible. So home to tea. || The first day in the East
is perhaps the day when one's impressions are sharpest. I felt
myself seeing the world with another perspective - perhaps a
truer one. Here was a world content to exist, pass its little
day + vanish, content perhaps with the knowledge that
before it passed it had laid the foundations of all the
existence of the future - the physical foundations if no
more, + after all they matter the most. "They live in eternity
said Ernest " like the ancient Egyptians" We who take
ourselves so desperately in earnest are probably doing no
more + with a vast deal more of agitation. || Ernest

came to fetch me at 7 whole I was talking to Mrs Ogilvy,
Mrs van Lennep's sister. As we drove out to Deir el Kubbeh
we talked of the impossibility of European govt. over
Orientals: ultimately they must find their own salvation.
A delightful dinner with him + Muriel in their charming
house. They say Gorst is doing everything exactly contrary
to the way the Lord did it + succeeding. The Khedive is
reconciled for the moment, the nationalists are disunited
+ without a leader. But crime increases - the fault
says Ernest of applying a Code Napoléon with a European
system
collaring
evidence. Ernest drove me back.
Thurs 28. To Sakkara at 9.30. When I got to the
Quibells' house I found they had gone to Cairo. But
lunched there + their man Ahmed took me to the
ruins. Furthest N is a big refectory with 2 lines of
columns. On the pavement the mark of the feet of the
monks when they stood looking towards the E + the
name of the monk cut on the stone. E of it a curious
chamber with 4 columns. Next to the S an open
court with a nimbar (but Xian) against the N wall
+ towards the E 5 columns
perhaps supporting a

done - something like the Ruweiha tomb. This may
have been a tomb? SW of it some large parallel
vaulted magazines of sundried brick. W S. of the
court the big church, a basilica with an apse on
either side of which are chambers making the E line
straight. Quibell tells me there are 2 apses, one over
the other + that the monastery was probably destroyed
at the time of the Arab invasion + rebuilt after, the
monks being then very poor + using up the materials
from the ruins any how together with sundried brick.
Part of the S wall stands, well built of faced stones
carefully fitted, a little rubble in the middle. All
along the S wall runs a water conduit + there are
lavateries on the outside of the wall. The conduit runs
on to a basin + water jar (of stone) just outside
the main door of the monastery. A door in the S
wall. A narthex of, I think, 3 chambers. Further
up to the W another small basilica with a quite
straight E end + slabs forming the sanctuary in
front. Slabs of marble in the E wall -
Then a mass of cells every where. So back

+ reached Bedrashin an hour + a half before the train.
Read + drank coffee. In at 6. || Oppenheim came at
6.30 + Moritz at 6.45. The latter dined + we talked
much of Mesopotamia. He advised the E bank of
the Euphrates + an excursion from 'Anah to the
Lakhmid castles. Oppenheim advised me to go
straight N into the hills from Urfa + so to
Diarbekr in the hope of Xian remains. || At 9.30
came Mr Quibell + we talked over the monastery.
Fri. 29. Left Cairo at 11 travelling to Port Said with 2
nice English women from New Zealand, Nurse Maude + Sister
Rose. Got in at 3.30. The boat left at 8.
Sat 30. We reached Jaffa at 6 + stayed there all day.
Read Sarhan. A Frenchman on board who has lived
much in C'ple, a boisterous little merchant. He thinks
German influence is gone forever, believes that the French
+ we have it all our own way. Says it was Said Pasha
who finally forced the Sultan's hand, not Izzet. Izzet
Mrs Ogilvy told me chartered his ship in the name of the English
governess in his family, Miss Bonual. She went with him
insisted on his marrying her, he refused + they quarrelled.
She is now in Paris. He left her this ship I believe as a
recompense.

Sun 31 Reached Beyrout at 6. || Fattuh + the head kavass
met me. Got through the Custom House without showing my
passport + with nothing opened. Went to the Cumberbatchs.
Rain showers, no snow on the lower hills.
Notes of talk - from Dr Jessop:
The 2 deputies are Suleiman el Bustani (Xian) +
Mudha es Sulha Moslem. The former is a very distinguished
man of letters, a Maronite of the Lebanon half way to
Saida. He has translated the Iliad into Arabic with a
very remarkable preface comparing pre Moham. with French
poetry. The latter is a large land owner native of Saida.
His record is not faultless but it was difficult to find a
Moslem with no reproach of bribery. He has done
well. He has already got an order from the Mejlis for
the enlarging of the Custom House, now lamentably
insufficient. Bastani at a banquet in C'ple made a
speech in Turkish, Arabic, Greek + French. The elections
passed here with the utmost order + in the best manner.
Story of Kiamil as Mutesserrif of Homs (?) The treatment
of the Nosairiyyeh was so bad that no Turk cd go
into the mts without an escort of 150 men. On the

other hand an American missionary of Lattakiyyeh
went in alone + was always well received. Kiamil
represented that Turkish policy in the mts was wrong
+ shd be altered. He was ordered from C'ple to hold
his tongue + obey orders. When he was Wali here a
prize tract was published by an English missionary
soc. dealing with truth, the absence of it among natives
+ the frequency of bribes. The Wali said it was contrary
to law + must be suppressed. The reply came but
why if it was true. He said it was like the
man who interfellated a one eyed judge thus:
Oh one eyed judge I know that
two caught right
the way, oh one eyed judge, etc. To which he
said: Well if I am one eyed I don't wish to be
reminded of it. The pamphlet finally slipped through.
From Mr C:
The Committee here had been formed after the proclamation
of the Const. came out into the open. Later a member
of the Salonica Committee Col. Saad ed Din + others came + reformed it
The members were then secret. They still remain to
watch sift + report. If any complaint is to be

=
Icrum Bey, Mutsserrif of Accra, Najin
addressed to them a letter must be sent to the Committee
of Beyrout + posted in the Turkish fort. They then look
into the matter, go to the Wali or report to Salonica. A
member goes to the Wali every day at least. When the
Mehmet Ali
Const. was proclaimed the Wali fled in terror + took
refuge with the English Consul who was then in the mts.
He fled sent him to the coast but he was intercepted + sent to
C'ple where he has remained unmolested. The present
Wali, Edhem Pasha, is the
5
th
since his removal.
He was preceded by Nazim who is now in Damascus.
Nazim rather licked the boots of the Com. so anxious
was he to stand well. He was rather suspect because
of the share he took in the Armenian massacres in
C'ple at which time he was head prefect of the police.
Druzes of the Hauran: report says that 10 regiments battalions
7-8000
are to be sent from Damascus to bring them to order
They have been turbulent lately + the feuds with the Arabs
continue.
Za'rifeh the banker
Mesopotamian irregation. Already from C'ple people are buying up
lands in view of an increase in Mesop. Merchants here are
preparing to do the same + in Cairo people are thinking of it.
Landed proprietors in Syria are now paying personal attention
to these lands rather than use the money to speculate in Cairo

Cotton at Haifa - Sursoks etc.
Prisoners were not let loose here. The mob asked for it
but the committee refused
but it was refused mainly owing to the representations of Mr. C.
The Austrian boycott was held up for nearly a couple of
months as the merchants found it was doing so much
harm. It is now replaced.
Mr. C. + I went to see the old Blisses (Dr Howard was
away) who are now very old. He was in bed with a
cold but I had a talk with him, mainly about Modern
Egypt. Then we went on to see Dr Jessop who came out
with the Blisses I think 54 years ago. A nice daughter.
A dim young man came to dinner.
Monday Feb 1. Went shopping in the morning + packed. Mr
Heard lunched. He has just come from Diarbekr + is
very gloomy about things there. Worse than the old régime
he says. The local committee is composed of violent
reactionaries, all scamps. The condition of the Armenians
in the country districts is awful. An organised attempt
has been made to exterminate them + in some places
it has pretty well succeeded. Drove with Mrs C +
Nancy to a garden on the Beyrout river. Mr Heard
dined. We had much talk of antiquities, particularly

danger of mob rule. So far has worked for good in Beyrout. Mob has insisted
on punishment of criminals, murderers hanged etc.
those on the Sajur + looked at Mr C's coins. Very pleasant.
Tuesday 2 My train left at 6.30. Gorgeous morning. Mr C
came down to the station where we witnessed the most
remarkable entraining of pilgrims from Bokhara. They
were packed so close that there can have been scarcely
room to breathe. The train was full + at the next
station we telegraphed to say they were to sell no more
tickets - my carriage being still empty! However two
people got in then. Wonderful journey up Lebanon.
At 'Ain Sofa we got into the snow. Lunch at
Reyak where we changed + reached Baalbek about 3.
Went to the German Hotel where I made great friends
with my innkeeper an old German called Zapf
He was for long years a merchant at Damascus.
Went straight out to the ruins which I thought
more splendid than ever. The magnificent masonry
gives it such a character. Also to the little temples +
the ruined mosque + the big stone + so in. Zapf
is full of hope as to the Constitution. He says the
peasants are very eager to hear about it +
delighted when he explains to them what it

really means. Agriculture has fallen fearfully low
owing to oppression + extortion. The peasants starve
through the winter + the beasts too. Yet the land is very
fertile. All Izzet's vast properties are confiscated; it is to be
hoped that the govt. will make it possible for the peasants too
become proprietors by waiting + giving them facilities for
purchase. The N end of the Anti Libanus is depopulated,
all the villages destroyed, inhabited only by thieves +
outcasts. The govt could find no way of ruling the
Metawileh there but extermination. The peasants are so
ignorant that in one village where a large mt prevented
the sun from shining there in winter, they attached
rings + ropes to the mt side + all the villagers turned
out to pull it away.
Wed. Feb. 3. Off at 5.30, moon setting over Lebanon,
very cold. Got to Hama at 10.30 + had an hour to
lunch. Walked out to my camping place + saw the
beautiful town. The rly follows the Orontes for
some way but turns off before Kal'at at Mudik.
Rain in the afternoon. Reached Aleppo at 4 + went
to the Palace Hotel which however is so horrid I

don't think I can stay. Went to the hospital + saw Dr
Altounyan about my hand. Nothing much. Then called
on the Griffeths at the Aziyeh. Horrible dinner in over
heated room full of Greeks.
Thurs. Feb 4. Determined to go to Aziziyeh + made the move at
once. Spent the morning in hotel. Tajir + Shellem came to see me;
Tajir about Tell Ahmar, Shellem assured me all was going
well - 4 Muslem deputies some of them good; good committee
composed partly of Xians. Mr Gracy, Miss Shaddock's agent
+ Dr Piper came to see Dr Griffeths + were introduced to
me. After lunch went to see Longworth about Tell Ahmar
Mr Fontana from Benghazir is appointed here. He was very
vague + sent me to Mr Christie whom I found in bed with a
cold. The Khourys presently appeared + we discussed the
Tell A. business. Christie well satisfied with events here,
chiefly I think on account of ovations to the English.
Then to Mme Koch, an amusing friendly lady. She was a
great friend of Ibrahim Pasha's + believes him to be alive
in the Jebel Sinjar. She says all is going ill here - the Vali
Reshid from Jerusalem is very weak, there is no govt.
crime has increased + goes unpunished there being

no one who can inflict punishment. Her next door natives
some Xians, have some mortal enemies who only spare
them because the Kochs live near them. Ahmed Riza gave
her letters to the Committee. They never turned up +
she believes there is no committee here. This seems
scarcely possible. She thinks there will be a row in the
spring because there is absolutely no authority in the town.
Formerly you could get things done by bribery; now nothing
is ever done. So to Dr Altounyan + home. ||
Friday Feb 5. Wrote letters till 11.30 when Fattuh came + I went to
his house + had an enormous lunch with Zakiyyeh + her
mother. Went down to the bazaar to see some horas + met
Mme Koch on the way. After seeing the horas we went
to see the Greek Catholic bp, Monseigneur Kadi. We found
a Jesuit + a Trappist with him. Presently Mme K + the 2
others left + the bp + I had a long talk. First he told
me that my sentence about him in my book, giving his views,
had caused great offence. M. Ali had told him about it
with a long face + said his opinions were most heterodox.
He said: there is no political question in this country;
everything turns on the religious questions, "ça prime".

He is sure the Xians will be worse off under the Const. + are
worse off. Liberty fraternity equality are empty words; the
Moslem will never admit equality with the Xian. The very
idea of a Xian Vali is unthinkable. When the movement
began he welcomed it instinctively. He told all his Xian
colleagues that on the whole it must be advantageous to
them. When representatives of the Sal. Com. came here all
his colleagues consulted with him as the advisability of
visiting them. He said, 'no they must come to us. We are
essential to them; they cannot do without us.' In effect
they came + were most friendly + polite. A Club of
Fraternity was formed + the Bps etc invited to attend
the opening ceremony. At Kadi's advice they all went.
He said they must give no cause for an accusation
that they were not favourable to the new régime. When
they arrived Kadi was put into the place of honour
at the right hand of the place reserved for the Vali.
The Vali did not turn up. The Moslems were
furious that a Xian should be presiding + they put
an old sheikh into the Vali's place so that a
Moslem shd be in the chair. After all the expressions

of brotherhood at the beginning, Kadi was in a company
of respectable Moslems. He urged that one of the 6
members for the vilayet should be a Xian. They replied
that that was quite unnecessary; were they not
all Ottomans? As a fact all
there
pledged not to
elect a Xian. He thinks the only reason why Moslems
in Beyrout voted for Bustani was that the Xian
population there is in a large majority; they were bound
to have one Xian deputy + they made the best of it.
Under the old régime some sort of govt. could be hoped for
from the Vali; he at any rate if a complaint
were brought to him, could order judge+ underlings to
execute justice. Now the Vali dare do nothing because
he is so afraid of committing an illegal act + the
judges etc will do nothing, there being no pressure
behind them. The result is a state of complete
anarchy. Men lie in prison for a month at a
time without trial or enquiry. He knows nothing
of a local committee. It is secret; he does not
know of any one to whom to apply. He believes that the
thing will end in anti Xian movement. Both in

Aleppo + in Damascus the anti X feeling has notably
increased. Formerly in Aleppo there was none; now
men who habitually consorted with Xians will no
longer be seen with them. He sees only 2 issues: either
the Const. will succeed + its principles be put into
action - which he does not believe; or it will
entirely fail, anarchy + a general murder of the
Xians will supervene + the Powers will be compelled
to interfere. He told me a tale of a Xian who desired
to become Moslem. In these cases a priest has to be
present to certify the willingness of the convert + the
latter must be 15. A priest went + found a veiled
woman who refused to uncover her face + declared
her age to be 40. He insisted on seeing her in private,
made her unveil as he had a legal right to do +
found her to be a girl of 12 who had been in his class
+ whom he had confirmed 2 years before. She
said she was unhappy at home + a Moslem wanted
to marry her. They returned before the judge, she veiled,
he told his tale + she again declared she was 40.
They made her unveil + the judge decided she could

not be more than 15 but might be that. Thereupon her
birth certificate was produced + it was proved that
she was only 12. She was therefore handed over to the
priest to be taken home. But at the door they were
stopped by a crowd of Moslems who threatened them
+ the zaptiehs with them. The priest was not allowed
to take her away, lest there shd be a row, but the
judge promised that at the earliest possible opportunity
she shd be returned to her family. This happened
since the Constitution. He knows Mutram + all his
family. Mutram has no following in Syria; even
one of his brothers has dissented openly from his
views. The Bp thinks that Syrian autonomy wd without
doubt be a disadvantage to the Xian community. The
Xian population in Syria is a smaller proportion
of the whole of Syria than the Xian pop. of Turkey in
proportion to the whole of Turkey. Moreover the Arab
is far more fanatical than the Turk. Therefore in
a practically independent Syria the Xian wd be
much more oppressed than he is under Turkish rule.
He thinks the Turks are the better rulers partly because

they are less fanatical, partly because they have a
long habit of rule behind them. He believes Mr Heard's
tales of the horrible state of the Xians E of Diarbekr .
Many Armenian refugees settled in Aleppo after the
massacres + many of them have property + land in
their old homes. After the Const. some went back
to claim it but returned to Aleppo empty handed;
the greater number made no attempt to go back
to their province. Went on to Mme Koch. She really
fears a revolution + uprising in the Spring. Von der
Goltz Pasha advised them all to go back to Germany.
She cannot leave her husband but she sent her
daughters home to Germany. She says she knows that
all the people she has nursed when they were
ill, helped out of prison etc, if once the fanatical
spirit were aroused, they wd kill her. Von der Goltz
told her if there was an anti Xian movement in the
Spring not one Xian wd be left alive in Turkey.
We talked carpets + Rakha ware. Then Koch came
in + a young man who is a clerk of theirs I
think; Fräulein Sophie + her brother + a

Herr Laubstein just arrived from Mosul + Diarbekr
a charming young man.
Sat. Feb. 6. A beautiful spring day. Mme Koch came at 9.30 + we
drove out by the beautiful Mamluk walls with the Lions (Euting thinks
them all Seljuk but Sarre Mamluk) past the Moslem cemetery +
to Wazir Khan where there is a splendid door. Koch has his office
here. Then to Khairubek Khan, much ruined. In the interior
a number of stone disks with a
cup
. 2 leaves springing from
the stem. On the
cup
hieroglyphics which the Mamluks brought
from Egypt - Euting still thinks them all Seljuk. Then by a
charming street fountain, one of the oldest buildings in Aleppo,
to the bank. Then to the Antioch gate. Near it is a ruined
minaret with a wonderful cornice decorated with Fatimid
rinceaux. On the gate are the Mamluk
cups.
On a mosque
near by, Jami' Elkikan, the Hittite stone. Mr Christie says
there is another which serves somewhere as a doorstep.
Went to the French consulate, Mr Roqueferier. He had some
good intaglios + a small Palmyrene figure. There is a
Palmyrene version of the Good Shepherd for sale in
Aleppo. M. Roquefort had an interesting tomb stone
of 2 granddaughters of Salah ed din dated I think

640 AH. Further there is a headless Hittite eagle in basalt.
In a street near the bank some fine Cufic inscriptions.
So back, meeting Fattuh busy buying a horse on the way, +
to lunch with Mme Koch. Then walked out to the citadel
+ lost my way in the bazaars coming home. Monseigneur
Dimitrios Cadi, Archeveque Grec-Catholique, came
at 3.30 + stayed till 5. His cousin is Abp in Damascus
of which city he is a native. Life is easier since
the Const. He can get letters + papers; there wd be no difficulty
in building a new church for which before a Firman was
necessary. (In the town Mme K. said I cd not under the
old conditions have photographed the fountain). His congregation
comes to him for everything - justice, relief, illness, guards.
They cannot be induced to provide for the future. They work
just enough to provide for the needs of the moment. They
waste a fearful amount of his time in long interviews,
bringing out their business only at the end as it wd be
rude to embark on it at once. Then if someone else
comes in they won't speak + the business is never done.
He hopes under the present régime to be able to part with
some of his Wakf lands + buy others, more advantageous

house property, in their stead - hitherto it has been impossible
to sell Wakf land. Then to Mr Christie + to the Kochs.
Took out £T150 + gave Fattuh 24 £T. Myself £T1.
Sun. Feb. 7. Wet again. Went early to the Consulate + photographed
one of the two Mamluk lions there. Then with Jusef into the
town. Saw the lovely Khan Sabun + the Khan el Gumruk.
In both the fine masonry + the discreet ornament is pare
passu like the best Greek work. Walked through the
Balistan bazaar + past the French consulate + then as it
was raining, home. || Fattuh bought 5 horses for £T51 ||
Shellem + Tajir came to see me. Lunched with the Kochs
where I met Herr Mygen, correspondent of the Berliner
Tageblatt. He has just come from Baghdad, Mosul,
Van, Bitlis, Diarbekr + Urfa. He is on the whole optimistic.
He attended in Bitlis a meeting of all classes + religions
+ heard excellent speeches advocating the building of
mines + forests also discussed
roads + railways + better education. At Urfa the new Club
is frequented alike by Xians + Moslems. At Urfa everything
is going excellently, Diarbekr has always been a fanatical
place, Xians + Moslems equally fanatical. The Armenians
at Xmas actually proposed a boycott of all Moslem

His impression is that governors + commandants all hesitate to commit
themselves to definite actions, thinking this state of things will not last.
shops. At Van it was the fault of the Armenians themselves
that they were not better represented. They selected a fanatical
Armenian, the more moderate voted against him + they +
the Moslems carried a Moslem. At Mosul he spoke with
Chaldaeans + Kurds. Both declared that the Armenians if
they had stood out against the Xians would have maintained
their position as well as the Chaldaeans have done. They
+ the Kurds are constantly at war but when the Kurds when
they are short of money + intend to raid a Chaldaean
village, send word that they are coming in 3 days + the
Chaldaeans send back word that they will be ready. The Armenians
are cowards + have gone under. Moreover most of their
leading men have gone to C'ple to make their fortunes +
left the others without guides + chiefs. It is true the Armenian
villages are in ruins but so are the Kurdish, owing to the
exactions of the govt. He was unable on one occasion to get
zaptiehs from a Kaimmakam. When he got to Diarbekr he
telegraphed complaints to the minister of the Interior. The
Vali apologised but said what was to be done? They
still had to work with the lower officials of the old régime
+ could get nothing done in consequence. They have not

yet the men; in 10 years it will be different. Went with Mme
Koch to the Tekkiyeh of Abu Bekr, a charming Mamluk
building of the same date as Khan el Wazir about - I
suppose late 15th or early 16th c. An exquisite Mihrab +
beautiful Arab lace work windows +coloured glass. The
wooden shutters have charming panels + some of which
are finely carved. Also a hamman, square with an
octagon above by means of pendentives + finally the
circle supporting a brick dome on 8 pendentives, a
delightful piece of construction. The Sheikh + his family
live in 2 little rooms off it, very delightful. Then to the
house of M. Andre Marcopoli. He has 2 stones one of
which is certainly Hittite, the other a rabbit looking
over its shoulder with a patterned background may
be Hittite. A good Assyrian relief, lots of tiles, in
Chinese china + one or two good pieces of Rakha.
Also a great number of bits of a very fine mosaic
dug up at Bilkis. Then on to Mr Georges Marcopoli
but it was too late + dark to see his things. The Vali,
Resid Beg came to see me while I was out + also
M. Homsi. Gave Fattuh £T40. (£T 65)

Mr Longworth says there are some Xians on the local committee
but it is very inactive.
Monday Feb 8. || Horrid day. Went in the morning with Mme Koch to see the
Vali. His wife whom I did not see is a niece of Hamdi's. Reshid
Bey
was Mutesarrif at Jerusalem when he got into trouble over the
selling of lands to Jews. His story is that the Jews had paid for
the lands + they had not been given them till he handed them
over. Other people say he made large sums out of the transaction.
The thing has still to be looked into + the accusation hangs
over him. He is a smallish man with a brown beard - I shd
say very intelligent. He said in his eyes the first thing to be done
was to reform the police, gendarmerie + justice. The police + gendarmerie
are too small in number. Also they are too little paid. || A
zaptieh gets 120ps per month. On this he cannot live decently.
But till the Budget comes out in March it is not possible to
augment the salaries or increase the number. The duty of the
police is to watch over the community, of the gendarmerie to
arrest + execute punishment; the first is the intelligence the
second the force. The whole system of justice needs reorganisation.
The judges receive from 600ps to 1000ps a month. This is
far too little - they have to eke it out by taking bribes.

The judicial system is complicated + delicate. It is frequently
not understood + rarely carried out with any perfection. It should
be simplified. As regards the religious questions: it is obvious
that as yet it wd be impossible to have a Xian provincial
governor. In C'ple there are Xians in the ministry. The
provinces wd not understand why a majority of Moslems
shd be governed by a Xian + they wd not obey. Little by
little it may become possible. The Xians will certainly be called
on to do military service. Xians are already being admitted
to the military college at C'ple. He thinks it wd be impossible
as yet to appoint Xians to a high place of command -
after all that is much the same distinction as that which we preserve
between English + natives in the Indian army. We then went
to Kostaki Homsi who has a most beautiful house in
Salubi. I bought some Hittite cylinders from him for £4.
He has a curious small basalt plaque this shape
with
figures in bas relief on it + an Assyrian inscrip. I am not sure
that it is genuine. A very fine small statue from Tell Lo,
a seated woman with the head turned to the left + a
Babylonian inscrip. An interesting bust of marble carved
in low relief with a boar's head + other figures. Also

some Rakha things, not I thought very good. So home to lunch
|| Fattuh has bought 3 more horses for £T23 but without saddles
or packs. And a donkey for £T5 + a bit.|| After lunch Mme
M Rouflet + I went out first to Bab el Hadid built by Melek el Ashraf ie Kait Beg where
Tamberlane made his entry. Near it in the bazaar is a
little mosque, much ruined inside, with two charming doors.
The time of one of the Mamluks - I think Melek ed Daher.
Note that the decoration of that time here is much less stylicised
than it wd be in Egypt. The rinceaux are more like Fatimid
work. Then on to the mosques + a bath near the citadel.
Went in to Jami' et Turush - quite ruined, a double
arcade on one side, the columns + roof fallen. An
interesting sort of water basin with arms, cups +
flagons. In one small turbeh not far off Malek ed
Daher is buried - we cd not get in. We went into the
Hammam + right down into the innermost underground
room where we found almost naked people making felt
mats in the dark! Then we went to the house of one Hajj
Hajj 'Amer, an antiquity dealer - a charming house, but he
was out. Delightful discreet stone work decoration +
inside the big room charming windows of coloured glass

The procureur général much overworked, he has to look after some 20 kazas
outside Aleppo - in consequence the work not done.
+ painted + lacquered wood work. So to the Murestan a
beautiful place built by Malek ed Daher, a courtyard
with a mosque + a tank. Inside a long vaulted passage
with square chambers opening out of it, domed + lighted
from the top. Some 8 cells, quite dark except for the
light from the top, in which the madmen were
chained up. They are criminal lunatics, they very seldom
recover + I don't wonder. So it has been ever since the
time of Malek ed Daher. Note in the court opposite the
mosque + in one of the cell chambers interesting oblong
brick domes. So to the Bab Kinnisrin a very splendid
place + walked along outside the walls which
are well preserved. 2 great bastions stand outside
in ditch. Turned off into the country near the Bab
Antaki crossed the line + up to a charming little mosque
called Sheikh M'ssein. Just below it on the hillside is
Meshed Hussein. Near it outside is buried a descendent of
one of the companions of the prophet. The mosque itself
was built by Saif ed Dauleh+ repaired by Melek ed
Daher. The decoration round the outer door + over the
liwan is very bold, an entrelac on a big scale

the Sultan has not given back nearly all his chifliks but on those retained
he now pays tithes amounting to £200000 to £300000 a year.
over the liwan. There is somewhere the stone on which is
the drop of blood that fell from Hussein's head when
it was brought here from Kerbela, but this the Sheikh
wd not show us. We saw in a small room a charming
Kibla niche flanked by two marble columns + rough
uncut acanthus caps certainly pre Arab. So back to the
house of Hamid Bey with whom I had a long talk. He was one of
the candidates for Aleppo but withdrew owing to his not being a native of the town. He said the Xians certainly
had the right to expect one out of the 6 deputies of the vilayet to be
a Xian but the different sects cd not agree, they ran 7 or 8
candidates + none got in in consequence. Moreover the Xian
community is a large minority, not one of the candidates
proposed was sufficiently distinguished for Moslems to vote for
him. The same thing happened at Marash where the Committee
had declared there was to be a Xian deputy. He thinks on
the whole the Xians will make no difficulties as to serving in
the army - except in the districts where the relations between
Xians + Moslems are always bad. Much interest was taken in
the elections. The committee reorganised by envoys from Salonica
contains Jews + Xians. They are in no way active. Their
duty is merely supervision + they must gradually disappear.

2 Clubs were started here. One which was open failed
for lack of numbers. The other was + is reserved for
the Committee but probably will be thrown open later. He
says the leading citizens of Aleppo + Catoni from
Alexandretta held a meeting to consider the rly question.
They pressed the govt to set at once about the Alexandretta
rly. The German concession gives the Germans first option
if any rly to the coast is to be constructed between
Mersina + Tripoli. They therefore suggested that the Germans
shd be asked to take it up, if they refused the
meeting decided to form a company themselves +
hoped to get foreign capital to help. Messrs Forbes,
the liquorice trust people, offered to undertake it
but they asked for a concession of land on either
side of the rly, a concession which will not now be
given. He says the Aidin rly has got the concession
to Bulghur. He praised the way the rly there
was managed. The Angora line can do without a
guarantee only in good seasons. They hope to make
use of the Albanians as a counter
point
to their
Bulgarian subjects in European Turkey. He

thinks but for the complications with Austria + Bulgaria
things wd have progressed much more rapidly. We talked of
ruins. He himself has property to the S. covered with the
ruins of early Xian villages. Even in the open country they
find traces of long walls which apparently divided the
fields. The land must all have been taken up. The
Vali said at the beginning Hurriyet was very badly
understood. Much was talked of rights + little of duties.
He was solemnly told that England wd give back Egypt
+ Crete + Austria Bosnia + Herzegovina. Disillusion
was bound to come for those who held such exaggerated
views as to what the Constitution meant.
Tues Feb 9. Went in the morning with M. Roqueferrier + M. Rouflart
to Firdaus. On the way we stopped to look at the ruined minaret
by the Antioch gate + found a beautiful Cufic inscrip. on it. Went
to a big cemetary round the mosque called As Salihin. Some
very good tombs with ornamented Cufic inscrips + the corners
decorated with vine rinceaux with bunches of grapes. Inside
the mosque is Abraham's footstep of enormous size. This
quarter contained the palaces of the Ayyubites. There was
also a Byz. cap which I photographed. Then round

across the fields by various kubbehs. A good many basalt
doors - from Jebel el Hass? So to the Turbeh from
which Rouflart got the tomb I saw at the Consulate.
And on to the lovely half ruined mosque of El Firdaus
where there is a mihrab with the bold entrelac above
it that I saw at Meshed Hussein. This mosque belongs
to the same period - it was built by the wife of
Melek ed Daher when she was regent for her son.
So home + to lunch with Mme Koch. Bought 10 naps
worth of cylinders from Hajj 'Amer. Then she + I
+ Rouflart went to the castle. The bronze gat iron
doors are dated Malek ez Zaher. One doorway is
ornamented with an entrelac of snakes, another
with a pair of Mamluk (?) lions. Inside are Mr H's
2 basalt Hittite lions. A great reception room
over the gateway, all ruined. Below it vaulted
chambers in which are built the Jewish gravestones
which Mr Christie told me are dated in the 13thc.
Therefore this front of the castle was probably restored
after the destruction by Tamburlane. It was he
who took away the revetment of stones from

the castle hill. The oldest thing in the castle (+ in Aleppo) is
a little mosque built by Nur ed Din, the last of the Atabegs
about 1100. There is a very fine carved wooden mihrab
in it, as good as some of the best Cairo work. Climbed
up the tower for the view. Rouflart went down the steps
to the bottom of the well which is I believe 80 metres
deep. He found vaulted passages for overflow water on
either side of it + a Cufic inscrip. Then went to see
Mme Reshid Bey a very attractive woman with
charming children. Reshid Bey was secretary to the
Sultan but was sent to Jerusalem, she thinks,
because he was suspected of having too liberal opinions.
At 5.30 Hikmet Bey editor of the Echo d'Alep
came to see me. He is the son of Nazim Bey who is
now governor of Konia. The committee consists here
of 300 people of whom 7 are chosen by secret ballot
to be the executive committee. I think Hikmet Bey
is one of these 7 + a certain Ismail Bey, an oculist
is another. He says for the next 2 or 3 years the
local committee will have to continue their function
of surveillance but they will gradually be merged

into a Parliamentary Liberal, or perhaps it might be
called Unionist, party. They have not a majority in
the chamber at present. The Aleppo committee has
local committee under it in all the smaller towns
of the vilayet. He was at Salonica for some years but
did not form part of the Committee or know much what
was going on. The paper does not as yet pay. He scoffs
at the idea of a reactionary committee in Diarbekr.
In the evening I went to the Club where I was received by
Hikmet, Ismail + others - one talked English. In the
little room of the directors of the Club were a number of
horrible objects, pictures + embroideries, made by the ladies
of Aleppo - they are to be sold for the benefit of the
Messina people. In the big ball was a long table with
papers on it + the portrait of Pasha at the
end of it. A good many people, mostly civilians were
sitting there. I was taken into a committee room
where the newly formed committee for commerce
was sitting - all sorts, one in a robe + a turban.
Then they made me a great ovation. I spoke to
them about the Muristan + they promised to see to it.

We talked of the Alexandretta rly. They said the chief business
of the committees was to educate the people. || So I left with
Vive l'Angleterre in my ears.||
Wed Feb 10. Mr Mygin came to see me at 9. Then with Mme Koch
M. Roqueferrier + M. Rouflard to the Firdus. There are some
very interesting caps in the Medresseh of Melek ez Zaher,
quite classical in form, but the decoration early Islam leaves
- very Sassanian - with dots down stalk + leaf like Ibn
Tulun. I think them the same date as the ruined minaret
by Bab Antaki. We saw a number of Turbehs, mosques
+ Medressehs + so back by the Bab Makam on which there
is a blazon (?) consisting of a dish with curve a whorl
or sun on it. So past the beautiful little Jamiet et
Tarwaki. Some of the caps on the outside are an Arab
imitation of the blown acanthus. Lunched with Mme
Koch. Then came Fattuh about horses. Then I went with
Jusef to the Jamiet el Helawiyyeh which was a
church. The dome still remains but it is as it stands
late, pendentives, tambour with 8 windows +calotte. Some
beautiful caps + an acanthus frieze inside. Some of the caps
blown acanthus of the date I shd think of Kal'at

Sim'an. Then to the bank + to the Maropoli's. I photographed
André's Hittite stones, walked about on the roof of the
bazaars, photographed the window of Khan es Sabun
+ then saw all Georges's Rakha - some very
lovely. He has too a very interesting silver repoussé
dish, the figures covered with gold. Twice repeated
Christ giving the sacrament to the people. An inscription
around. Hamid Beg came to see me.
Thurs. Feb 11. Wrote letter to the Times all morning. Lunched
with Mrs Koch. Then to the Antioch gate to photograph the
minaret. Met Nahleh in the bazaars who took me to a
dealer in the Khan bazaar who had nothing particular.
Then to the big mosque under the citadel where I could not
get in. Then to the 'Adliyyeh. Charming court with
columns + over the windows beautiful tiles but the
people were disagreeable + would not let me in. So
through the bazaars where I met Fattuh + watched
him buy tents + odds + ends - a wonderful scene.
So home to tea with Mrs Koch + then to visit Elias
Hindié.
Fri. Feb 12 Went to the Khourys with Mme Koch. He had

some lovely Rakha fragments with most interesting
Sassanian decoration, the wing pattern quite complete
only lacking the king's head of the coins. But as he asked
£20 for them I did not buy. Then to the Greek Catholic
church where there is very beautiful decoration under
Arab influence. The canopy over the altar fine;
pillars with a rinceaux of flowers + leaves running
diagonally round them + Arab entrelac on the cornice.
Then to the ruined Maronite church which is now a dye
house (basmaji). It has been a basilica with 4 aisles;
the caps + wood work fine Arab. Photographed a beautiful
house in the Saliby + lunched with Mme Koch. Wrote after
lunch, inspected my tents + shopped. To tea with Mme
Koch + Mygin. Dined with Elias Hindié + went after
to the house of Nasry Homsi. There I met a very interesting
man, Mikhail Shakar, who was learned in Arab
literature. We talked politics + they all asked me
whether we wd not intervene + send "teachers" into
the provinces for the govt was weak + could do nothing
by itself. Every one needed training. One of the young
Homsis asked why there shd not be a Xian Vali in

Beyrout but Homsi said I was right in saying it was
impossible. They all think the govt. will break down.
They said the Moslems wd not allow them a single
member for Aleppo vilayet. I asked whether they
had all agreed upon a candidate. No, they had
brought forward as many candidates as the Moslems
did; the Xian sects could not be induced all to
vote for the same man. Finally Shakar admitted
that if they had all agreed on one man perhaps
they wd have got some of the Moslems to vote
for him though he had said at first that in any
case the Xians were too few in number to carry
a member + the Moslems wd not help them.
Mr Christie subsequently told me they certainly would have
carried a Xian because they would have had the whole
Jewish vote.
Sat. Feb. 13. Wrote letters + out to the bank at 10 when Jusef
joined me. We went to see an old church that Sakkar had
told me about, near the Khan Wazir - it is now a
basmaji, dye place. The work is Arab. A centralized
building with a dome over the middle but no

columns. The dome had fallen, it had been set on
stalactite pendentives. The apse was a square, deep
livan with large chambers on either side. To the left the
dome was standing, brick on pendentives. I doubt
whether it was not a mosque but had no compass with
me to determine the orientation. So to the fort + to the
Abp Kadi whom I found in his room with a cold. He told
me how his people came to him for everything, complaints,
difficulties, misdeeds; he had their complete confidence + they
told him what they told no one. It was very difficult to give
them an enlightened view of religion: they are so fanatical. He
tries to show them that a good Moslem will go to heaven whereas
a bad Xian won't. If he attempts to prove to them that every
small event is not a miracle from heaven, they immediately
conclude that the miracles in the Bible are not to be
believed. (Here they show more logic than the Abp would
have admitted!) When he enters a house it is the
custom that he shd sprinkle holy water; this they regard
with a superstitious reverence that is perfectly preposterous.
But with the poor people he cannot dare to point out that the
benefits they attach to the ceremony are not given it

on the authority of any known scripture: they wd instantly lose
faith in all other rites. He told me a curious story of a
woman of his congregation in Paris who had a dangerous
+ successful operation. She insisted on regarding it as a
miracle of the Virgin's, to the immense annoyance of her
doctor + it was only dissuaded from publishing the
account of the said miracle by the Abp's finally convincing
her that it wd give unbelievers reason to mock. He
says the iconostasis does not occur before the 8thc
but the sanctuary was marked off much earlier
by low stone or wooden slabs. He supposes the Greek
church took this from the Jews. Lunched with Mme Koch
+ afterwards rode to 'Ain Tell on my new mare accompanied
by Jusef. On a mill there, I saw 2 Mamluk lions
over the door, + inside there was a fine basalt
door. All these had been dug out of the tell. Some
Xians were engaged in dying at the spring. One cheerful
person said that if the Constitution had been worth
anything the poor wd not have to work like that. I said
At least you have your
nammusiyyah
cheaper + he
admitted that that was something. So to tea with

the Christies. He told me the Jews had been settled here since
the time of the Maccabees. There is an old synagogue
which contains a Hebrew bible, written (I think written) by
Maimonides in the 13thc - a very important text. So to Mrs
Koch's where I met M/ Henrich. An English Colonel
has arrived here. His name is Bailward + he has stayed
with the Spring Rices at Tehran. He is deaf + not very enlightened.
Sun Feb 14. Packed all morning with intervals of seeing Zakiyyeh,
Tajir, etc. Lunched with M. Roqueferrier - there were there Mr
Longworth, M. Scanziani of the Ott. Bank, Henriez who is very
nice, Rouflard, Henri Marcopoli, a M. Ballit I suppose a dragoman.
The lunch lasted exactly 3 hours + was pretty dull. Mme Koch + I
went + came away together. There is a charming minaret by the
Bab el Faraj with a Cufic inscrip. round. Watched Fattuh
pack + then called on the Hindiés + the Kochs. He was up
but looking very ill. Home to dine + talk with Mr Beard of the
Liquorice Co (there is another young man whose name I don't
know) + Col. Bailward.
Mon. Feb 15. Very warm + misty.|| I got up at 6.15 + we got
the baggage off at 8. I have with me 3 muleteers. Hajj Amr
who was with me when I went to Antioch, Habib

+ Selim, the two first are to get £T2 a month; the latter £T3.
I have 2 soldiers who are to go to Rakka with me, Abbas
Chowwish a Turk, + Hajj Muhammad. I left at 8.30 with
Abbas + Mr Mygind who rode out with me for an hour
+ a half. Beautiful warm morning. We talked politics,
English + German relations etc. || He said he had found our
consular service better than theirs; both in Urfa + in
Comez + Major Dickson had been his best sources of
information for their towns. In Baghdad when the Committee
asked the leading consuls to a function, the English
+ French went + the German refused because he had no
instructions. He thinks if the Constitution breaks down it
will be the fault of the Xians. We parted with many
expressions of esteem. Abbas Chowwish + I rode on
together + presently Jusef rode up from behind (he
had been with the mules) + joined us. Fattuh did not
appear till long after, having been detained at the
post office. The country is monotonous, rolling cultivated
ground. They work the fields every second year. Last
year the locusts came + this spring the ground is
full of the crysalises eggs. We saw the peasants grubbing

them up + the govt pays them by weight for the eggs. None
the less they do not work at it very hard + I expect
there will be a plague of locusts this year. The eggs are
only in the unploughed ground + wherever they are
the ground is pitted as if it had smallpox. We passed by
Sheikh Najar + Sh. Ziyad where I went up to see the Ziyara
but there was nothing old in it; only a clay tomb. We left Serbes
to the right + did not see it - it was beyond a ridge. There was
a very small Moslem village called Shammar about half way.
Several Tells + a good many cisterns - jubl - cut in the
rock. After 5 hours riding we came to Tell el Hal which
was one of the best examples of an old site with a mud
village lying under the Tell. Just before it was a column
base with a moulding at the spring of the shaft + beyond
the village in the graveyard were a number of fragments of
columns. I climbed the Tell but found no pottery of any
interest. Fattuh joined us soon after we left Tell el
Hal. We saw the high minaret of the Zigara above El Bab
an hour before we reached it. We got to El Bab at 4 -
71/2hours + the mules took exactly 9. Went to the Khan. We
had a shower of rain in the morning + one in the

afternoon, nothing much. Walked out into the town + saw a
ziyara with a stone dome + some rather nice but rough
wood work before the tomb. Then climbed to the high Ziyara
of Sheikh Hashil. The foundations of the building are certainly
old big stones dressed round the edges + left rustic in
the middle. The actual tomb was locked. From the
minaret fine view of the beautiful fruitful plain, strewn
with villages, reaching up to the Jebel Hass. I counted
4 tells in it, no doubt all artificial. As Fattuh had not
been there I had lunched off a bit of bread from A. Ch.
+ a little chocolate in my pocket. I also had no tea
so I was very hungry when my dinner came in at 7.30.
Tues. Feb 16. I got up at 5.45 but a heavy shower delayed loading +
the baggage was not off till 7.50. We left at 8 + got in to
Bumbuj at 3.15; the baggage came in at 4.45, a long day.
We rode across the sort of valley there is at El Bab + onto
rising uplands all cultivated. The barometer went up
250 ft at the highest part of the road but dropped again
to the same point as at El Bab when we got to Bumbuj.
It may however have varied a little by reason of the
strong wind we had during the day. There was a

little rain but not much. About an hour after leaving El Bab
we were joined by a charming Circassian from Bumbuj,
Mahmud Agha. His father came from Russia but he was
born at Bumbuj. They went first from the Caucasus to
Roumeli where they settled down + built houses; then the
Russians took that land also + they again let all + came
here where they are well content. But if the Russians came
again wallahi he didn't know where they wd go. We reached
Arime in 3 1/2 hours. There I saw the inscrip. on the
column copied by Mr Hogarth + in a house a large stone
with an inscrip. of Melek ez Zaher
...
that was all I cd read. Also above this place a
fragment of a bas relief with a pair of feet + one
simple foot, in shoes not pointed + not I shd think
of any period before Rome. Mahmud Agha told me that
all the Arab fellahin in the villages had no votes because
they wd not register themselves. If they but thought they
were "written down" in the books of this Govt. they would
all take to flight at once. At Bumbuj + round about there are only
1000 voters out of a much larger possible number.
He had a vote + knew the names of all the Aleppo

vilayet deputies. He also told me that now all people were
equal, all were to have equal justice + none were to wait
for months before the Seraya cd be got to attend to them -
+ then only with bribes. He saw no difficulty as to Xians
serving in the army but thought they cd not rise very
high in the service. Fattuh was away when the election
took place. He is not inscribed. Before we reached Bumbuj
we saw a great kanat on either side. Mahmud said
they came in to the town from all sides but the E (where
the water runs down to the Euphrates) + still bring water.
There is a large + very deep pond just inside the ruined
line of the walls at Bumbuj, fed by an underground
spring. We put up at a khan + I went out + photographed
the sacred pond + walked half round the line of the
walls till I came to the site of the theatre. The Circassians
have dug down into the walls + taken out the stones. There
is a great open space within them scattered over with
featureless ruins. Then I visited a little mosque with a
Ziyara of Sheikh 'Akil. He was living in Bumbuj,
Mahmud told me, when Timur Long besieged the city.
He sent in a message to the Sheikh who had a great

reputation saying he intended to take the town. The Sheikh
asked him to wait 3 days + on his advice during those days
the inhabitants themselves ruined the city, whereupon Timur
passed it by. Near the khan is a new mosque built by the
Sultan on the site of a mosque of Malek ez Zaher's. Nothing
was left of the latter but a ruined minaret (I doubt whether
Murray is right in speaking of an inscrip. of Salah ed Din
- the 3 now remaining are all of M. ez Zaher) this was
pulled down + the new + very ugly mosque built. Below
its pavement they found another which they say belonged
to the Xian church. There were a good many columns
about + one cap. but it was antique not Xian.
When the mules came in I watched them being watered in the
sacred pool. The cold wind dropped + my room is large +
comfortable with my own furniture, but the double door won't
shut by a good inch + more. Tomorrow the Euphrates, plans
of Carchemish + of joining my camp at Tell Ahmar in the
evening having been stopped by Hajj Muhammad: "Oh my
brother! it is the Euphrates." Remember a greeting from
an old man with a donkey + a rifle: "Whither going in peace?"
"To Carchemish." How often must that have been said!

Wed Feb 17. Left Bumbuj at 7.15 with Jusef + Hajj Muhammad.
We found a number of villages not marked in Kiepert, the first 2 on
the left being Mangabeh + Wardana; after them on the right 'Ain
Nakhileh. A man on a donkey joined us + talked with Hajj M.
about Hurriyeh. He was not inscribed nor were any of the
villagers + none of them from these Arab villages had done
military service. He knew nothing about the new govt. Presently
we dropped into the Sajur valley at Chad + followed the river by
a narrow much washed away path on the side of the hill, to
Ausheriyyeb which we reached at 10.15. A few yards more brought
us into sight of an arm of the Euphrates flowing under white
cliffs in which were big chambered caves. We rode half an
hour
or so down the bank till the two arms joined making a
stream about as big as the Thames at Chelsea + at 11 we
came to the ferry. Camels, carts, donkeys were waiting to
be taken over - the camels had been waiting 2 days, in yesterday's
wind no boat could cross. The camel drivers were very
sorry for themselves, no bread, no fire no tobacco by god.
So we got across the widest part, rode over a stretch of
sand + stones + were ferried again over another narrower
arm. When the snow melts all this broad extent

is covered with water. Tell Ahmar is washed by the waters
of the Euphrates + the village lies at its N foot. I climbed
onto the mound + lunched there. We saw our baggage animals
arrive at the ferry an hour behind us. Then I took one
Ibrahim + went out to see the stones. We walked across open
desert to the walls which are easily distinguished as
a long mound. At the E gate we saw the 2 Assyrian
lions of Shalmaneser + just inside it the broken stela
with 2 heads visible. We followed the line of the wall N
to the N gate which is clearly visible. N of it outside
the walls is a little mound with a cave (filled up with
earth) + the broken Hittite stone or stones. These we dug
out with the assistance of a large number of people. Ibrahim
told me he was not popular with the Kaimakam of
Bumbuj + proposed to put himself under my protection
please God. On one of the stones there was a bull. A
discussion arose as to the nature of the animal + Ibrahim
said it was a pig. Hajj M: "In the ancient days they made
pictures of men + maidens, horses, bulls, dogs + lions. But not
of pigs." Ibrahim with conviction: "They did not make pictures
of pigs." I then made a cast of one of the stones - it

took me 2 hard hours, + came in at 5 to tea. Lovely warm
evening; the sun set behind the Euphrates. Barometer dropped
nearly 500 ft between Bumbij + here. Some say Membij, I hear,
both Jerablus + Jerabis - I think the people here say the latter.
Thurs Feb 18. Worked from 8 to 12 at the inscriptions. Ibrahim +
'Isa learnt to make rubbings + did the job very well. We gave
innocent pleasure to a large company of observers. There are 5
stones. No 1, outside the hole, has a continuous inscription on 2
sides running over the rounded corner, + on the other small side
the hind leg of a bull. Nos 2, 3 + 4 are inside the hole. No 2 has
a bull over an ornament of flowing volutes. On another side a
largish inscrip. which Mr H. saw, + a small much worn
fragment on a third side. No 3 is inscribed continuously on
2 sides, the writing running over the rounded corner. On a third
side are the legs + upturned shoes of a man one of whose feet
rests on the head of an animal, + on a 4th a fragment of
inscription. No 4 is only a fragment with a bit of inscrip.
on one side - all the other sides are broken. No 5 is
outside the hole. It has an inscrip. on one side running
over the corner + a bit of an arm on the other. In the
village I saw: A black stone with 2 men in relief,

turned up shoes, part of a procession. A white stone with 2
griffins one on either side of a tree. A black stone with a
bird headed, winged man. After lunch photographed +
copied the new part of No 3 + turned over the stones.
Then rode with Ibrahim + Muhammad, a native of Kubbeh,
down the river + saw 2 Hittite stones, one a small fragment,
one a large stone upside down, + a mound with a
black stone lion's head lying broken off on it + his body
buried + said to be inscribed. This we must dig out.
Hard day's work.
Friday Feb 19. Wind + rain in the night.
Arabic text
as Fattuh says.
At 8 it cleared a little + I sent off men to dig out the stones between
here + Kubbeh. At the first place there was no inscrip. on the black
stone + on the white only a much effaced relief so I copied
the other black fragment + went on to the lion. We dug him out
+ found only his legs in relief + no inscription. Rode then with
Muhammad Agha + his brother 'Abed, both Kurds of Kubbeh,
to Mughara where there was nothing + on to some caves
further down the river. Before we got to them there were
remains of some construction in fine white cut stones
- Roman, I wonder if it can have been a bridge? Near

it a number of graves from which the peasants said they got
glass + gold rings. I saw 2 broken sarcophagi, quite plain,
that they had got out of the ground. The caves were uninteresting;
one had a cross incised over the door. So on to Tell Kara
Kazak which Kiepert calls Kyrk Kazark. At the foot of it
remains of buildings, cut stones + massive door jambs.
So back through storms of rain. In the graveyard of Kubbeh
I copied a Latin inscription. Got in at 2.15 + lunched.
After which I finished up some photographs here +
wrote to Mr Hogarth. Wind + rain.
Sat Feb 20. Still + clear. We sent a messenger at dawn up to somewhere to bring a shahtur to Kumluk and
rode off at 7.30, Fattuh, Hajj M. + I. At 8 we reached Tell el 'Abr where
I bought a charming triple god which had come from Kürk Mughara
for 11/2 mej. The Shahtur was there but half full of water, so we
sent up to the village for a tin to bail it with + meantime I rode
1/4 of an hour to Tell el Kumluk where there were bits of columns
in the graveyard + a large black stone in the middle of the mound
Behind, near the hills, a Tell + village called Bada'a.
but not visible inscription. So back to the boat. Hajj M's horse
made a tosheh with Fattuh's + we decided to leave him behind
moreover a sharp little west wind had risen + the men doubted
whether we cd get over. But we went + were carried 1/4 of a

mile down stream + presently landed - on an island! It seemed
that the further arm had risen in the night + it was doubtful
whether we cd get over. There were 4 men with us + they
gathered up their clothes + went it. By dint of making a long
curve over the shallows we got over with water up to our girths.
But the stream was swift + once my mare was turned half
round. There is a road by the river but the water had come up +
we cd not got that way, so we rode in land for half an hour
over the bluffs, a bare rocky country with a lot of ruins in
one place, door jambs + cut stones (Kiepert marks it
Klosterruinen) + in a valley further away a village. So down
to the Euphrates again + over the plain for an hour to a little
tell by the river with a village beyond it, also called Jerablus
or Jerabis - the first name is Turkish, the second Arab - 1/2 an
hour more brought us to the huge mound. On the N E side is the
citadel washed on 2 sides by the river. The high earth works
that mark the walls stretch out from it in a circle away
from the river; the gates can be made out I think. Inside are
masses of ruins in great blocks, foundations of walls, pave-
ments, the line of one of the streets + a good many broken
columns with marked caps. In the hill are the 2 carved

blocks the Brit. Mus. left + near them the broken fragment of a
third, a winged personage. The view from the top of the citadel
is superb. I lunched + then arrived Salim Nebky a friend
of Fattuh's + Catoni's. He + his 6 brothers are landed
proprietors + run with Catoni a liquorice factory in Alexandretta.
Much talk of the rly surveyors for the bridge who have
recently been here. Salim told me that the remains of the
town stretch all round for far away. At Kerakli, a
village in the valley to the N, there is a Hittite stone which
has been photographed + copied. Far away in the hills to the
SW is a cave with loculi - Fattuh + Mr Hogarth visited
it. We got to the tell at 12, rode down to Nebky's village -
also Jerablus or Jerabus, + left at 2. At 4.5 we
were back to the river + found the shahtur waiting. Also a
crowd of men + 4 donkeys eager to cross. Fattuh turned
half of them out. We grounded on the end of the island
but our fellow passengers got out into the water +
pushed + tugged us into the main stream. At 4.45
we landed + 20 minutes later were back in our tents.
Bought a small white stone at Jerablus with a lion on
one side + a star on the other for 3/4 mej. Great day but
I was tired when I came in.

There is a big Chiflk, of which Bumbij is the centre, that reaches to the
Euphrates. It ends at some point between Tell Ahmar ferry + Jerablus.
Sun Feb 21. Off at 7.55. We followed the road to Kubbeh, Ja'deh (to the
right) + Mughara which we reached at 10.55. Then up the hill leaving
the Euphrates to the right -we did not see it again. At 11.20 we
were opposite a village called Kayik Debü about 1/2 a mile off the
road to the E. At 11.45 we saw traces of a ruined village 5 minutes
E of the road. At 12 we came to Serin Serra lying under its Tell + camped
opposite near a little stream that flows from an 'ain about 1/2 a
mile away. A Xian called Georgi lives here + collects liquorice
for the Nebkys. Besides the villages marked by Oppenheim there
is one beyond Metras called Gaur Kharab. I lunched + then rode up
the hill to Oppenheim's tower tombs. The one to the N which has the
Syriac inscrip. is about 1/2 an hour from Serrim Serim. Near it are a good
many rock cut tombs in caves with a passage sloping down to
them, but all are filled with stones + rubbish. There is a curious
mixture of classical + unclassical (such as the stylobate of the
upper engaged columns) details. We rode half an hour through
the bare hills to the S. tomb which is a good deal ruined. Only the
S side is perfect. Oppenheim says they were doubtless crowned with
pyramids: they may have been but one cannot be certain

till one has climbed to the top of the N tomb - the second is too
much ruined. The porphyry block he calls a sarcophagus.
Georgi was very full of Ibrahim Pasha who crossed below
Kal'at en Nejm on his way back from Damascus,
swam
the river on horseback he + 100 men with him. They passed
through Serim on their way back to Viransheher. Georgi does
not believe him dead. Fine view from the S tomb. We saw
K. en Nejm + down to Masudiyyeh + all up the river.
To the E a rolling desert country; nothing visible S of
Oppenheim's road but Arab tents. We are about 100 ft above
Tell Ahmar. It was hot today; the temp. in my tent at 4.30
was 64o. Last night it froze a little. There were a few Arab
tents near the village here. The Arabs here are the Beni
Sa'id, belonging to the Fahl. The Great Sheikh of the Fahl is
'Abd at Tamr. There is everywhere in flower a small white
bulbocodium which sometimes flushes to a pale mauve.
Mon. Feb 22. When the sun rose at 6.30 he found us breakfasting
outside my tent + very glad to see him for there was a sharp
E. wind. Went up onto the Tell where there are a number of
cut stones - lintels or door jambs? - but no inscriptions.
They say a marble stone was found near the mill at the

A woman cursed us for not giving money to her baby + immediately after Jusef's
horse fell down!
'Ain with pictures on it, but the Arabs broke it. One man said
Ibrahim Pasha passed here with 800 horses. Left Serim at 7.35 with
Jusef + Hajj M. + rode down the valley towards the Euphrates. We
saw Kala'at en Nejm in front of us. Turned up a bare valley to
the left + came to a great cave inhabited by Arabs with a
curious inscrip. in it - script unknown. This was 8.55.
Rode on up the valley + out onto a wonderful rolling marj with
a few black tents on it. There are only Arabs of the villages round
about but when the grass grows all the 'Anazeh camp here.
Their chief Sheikh in these parts is Hakim Beg. So down
to Mas'udiyyeh on its tell 10.20 - 10.40. On the top of the
tell is a house + I saw outside it one of the pavements described
by Oppenheim, but the other with the inscriptions has been
washed away. The baggage caught us up here + we rode on
over a long stretch of sand. At 11.10 passed near a small
Tell called Tell el Banat which lies about a mile from
the river. A few minutes later we passed by some tents of
Sheikh Hamud of the 'Amirat who
came
down here.
At 12 we reached a ridge of hills + by a graveyard I got
off + lunched till 12.30, the baggage going on. At 12.30
we went on through a pass between the bare rocky hills

+ at 1.30 were down on a wonderful stretching grass country
bounded by the Euphrates on one side + a semicircle of low
hills on the other. In the centre was a hill called El Kulaib
+ the soft light lay over all. This land belongs to the Weldi; we
saw their black tents scattered over it. So down to the
wide reach of sand called Er Ramleh + Er Ramaileh,
by the Euphrates, + then we found a small encampment
of 8 tents, one of which belonged to Sheikh Sallal of the
Weldi. His son Muhammad came out to welcome us; he took
us to his tent + made coffee + presently Sallal came in. He
had been to Meskeneh with locust's eggs which they
destroy there. As this is not govt. country the Arabs are
not paid for the eggs Sallal is in reduced circumstances
owing to a quarrel with the govt about (I think) his brother
who was taken for a soldier + deserted. Whereupon the govt
siezed Sallal's flocks + clapped him into gaol for many
months, first in Deir + then in Aleppo. Finally he sold his
best mare for £37 + got out. Now he has nothing + Heaven
knows how they live. He asked Hajj M about this new
Govt + received no encouraging answer - Hajj M.
thought Liberty in these parts an empty word; many

men were still killed every week in Aleppo + for his part he
did not know what the envoys did that they sent to C'ple. We
talked of Ibrahim Pasha whom Sallal pronounced a great robber;
he used to descend upon them + carry off their cattle. On the
rising ground behind the tents are little mounds each of
which has a ring of great stones round it. I saw 5 of
them + in the biggest were foundations of rectangular chambers.
Stones lay also about the tents, but very few cut stones. I
think it must have been a Byz. place for Muhammad
had a Byz. coin found here. When he had shown me all
Muhammad said reproachfully "You haven't laughed
once, not when I showed you the ruins nor when I told
you the names of the hills." There is a big Chiflik on the
other side of the river, with its centre at Abu Galgal. It
reaches to Meskeneh. The inhabitants of Chifliks do not
do military service. Fattuh saw a ragged Arab this
morning who came begging for tobacco. He was riding a
mare worth £200. Only 2 eggs here; we paid 4 metaliks a piece
for them. Cold wind all day but this evening after sunset it is 58o
in my tent.
Tues Feb 23. We left Ramaileh at 7.30, Abbas Chowwish, Muhammad

ibn Sallal + I, rode on the sand in a high wind. At 8.15 we went
back to the higher ground E of the sand + reached a place called
Sheikh Shems ed Din where there were traces of building. About
half a mile from the river. Below it 5 min. away on the edge of
the sand more remains of ruin. At 8.40 we climbed up again
+ found bits of cornice, very elaborate acanthus frieze
+ decorated details, lying among cut stones. This is still
called Shems ed Din. A little further on, on a rock above
the sand Muhammad said there had once been a lion
carved but the Arabs had shot at it + destroyed it. A
small Tell called Tell Ajwayf by the river at 9.10
Tell ed Daher below Sheik Sin 9.35 - traces of
ruins, uncut stones. Then up to the top of Sheikh
Sin 10 - 10.20. No ruins on it. The position of the tells
is thus:
Tell Sheikh
Havan
305
Tell el Qara
Jerniyyeh
Arodeh
Hunbaya
120
141
Sheikh
Sin
Tell ed
Daker
Euphrates

I reckon it about 5 miles from Sheikh Sin to Jerniyyeh. Seeing
there was so much to be examined I sent Abbas to tell the
baggage to camp at Munbaya + rode on to Jerniyyeh with
Muhammad. A high wind against us. We met some
charming Turkish pedlars who gave me raisins. Galloping
a good deal of the way we got to Jerniyyeh at 11.30 +
stayed till 12.35. On the top are 3 mounds into which
the Arabs have dug + uncovered cut stones. It looks
as if there had been towers or tower tombs here. Below
at the S W corner is a low mound ringed round with a
wall. N of it + S of the Tell is a large area of
ruins, none of them cut stones but the foundations of
houses clearly marked. Among them a jubb now waterless
but there is water in another jubb to the E. Abbas joined
us + we lunched here + rode back to Tell el Gara,
which we reached at 2.10 - 2.25. There has been building
on it + there is lots of coloured pottery, I think early
Arab. We picked up too a Byz. coin. So we rode into
Munbaya, which Kiepert calls Bersiba, + found our
camp in the middle of it. Arrived at 2.45. Had tea +
planned the mound. Immense cut stones visible

in the outer wall, away from the river, + on the river side
where the water has swept the stones out. Wind
dropped but grey.
Wed Feb 24. The wife of Ahmed el Bursan came to see
me before I left, a pretty woman. He has 4 wives. He is
the Sheikh es Shuyukh of the Weldi of the Jezireh. A
beautiful still morning. We left Bersiba at 7.40 + rode
along the river bank. At 8 we reached Tell Sheikh
Hassan. Half way between it + Mungara there were
ruined foundations by the water's edge. On the S side of
the Tell a very large stretch of ruins among which I saw
a rude capital. At 8.30 reached El 'Arāb, walls +
mounds as of a walled town. Then down onto the low
ground past Weldi tent + at 8.45 got to Tell Jifneh
a little off the road to the E + about 1/2 a mile from the
river. It stands on the edge of the grassland. Here too there
were ruins - to the N of the Tell. We rode for some time over
this low ground + then up onto the grasslands again + at
10.20 got to Hallāweh, ruins standing over the river.
5 minutes further was a graveyard called 'Ammash.
At 11 Tell Murraibet standing right over the river.

Low mounds to the N of it but the town must either not
have been very large or it must have been so old that
all the stones have disappeared. At 11.50 we halted
in the midst of Naif's encampments. The baggage
came up at 12.15 + I lunched till 12.35. Past
Na'if tents at 12.45. At 1 we were opposite old Meskeneh.
At 2 we reached the big tent of Sheikh Mabruk
whose father Suleiman died a few month's ago. We
could get no corn here + rode on for a little to a further
encampment but returned to Mabruk's tent where we
camped behind some stacks of liquorice. I drank
coffee in the Sheikh's tent while the tents were being
pitched - he is away. All the Weldi are enchanted
that Ibrahim Pasha is dead. They say he wrecked the world + they
did not dare to go up to their pastures in the hills while he lived.
Since he has gone all has been quiet: "Nistarih." We have
lodged all our 13 animals in the Sheikh's tent. We are
camped a little way below Dibse. I can neither see nor
hear anything of the tower marked in Kiepert as being to the
E. of the river here. Camels can ford the river above Dibse in the
summer. There is a safineh at Meskeneh + one at Arodeh.

No Safineh from Meskineh to Rakka. We are nearly opposite
Dibse - a little lower down - which is Thapsaeum. A
little cultivation, but very little. Oats + khuntar.
Thurs Feb 25. Clear beautiful day. Off at 7.15 with Ibrahim,
a young man of the Sheikh's house as guide. He was a most
pleasant companion. After we had ridden
hour hours
he said there
was a ruin in the hills to the E about 11/2 hours away called
Mudawwarah, but we did not go to it. We left the road + galloped
up to the hills where there was a good rock cut tomb called
Mahall es Safsah. I planned it 10.15 - 10.45. Then straight
down to the river to Tell el Efra'i. At 10.45 got to an
immense dyke that runs round it from the Euphrates
enclosing a big space. The Tell is very large. We saw big
stones, some squared, washed out of it.
Dyke
Tell
Euphrates
K. Ja'bar
27
129
97
Tell el Efra'i
263
83
The readings are taken from the W. end of the Tell to
the tower of Neshaba + the minaret of K. Ja'bar.
Tell 11 - 11.20. Neshaba 12 (foot of hill) - 12.30.
Kal'at Ja'bar 1 - 3. Neshaba is a tower of uncut

stones laid in much mortar. All the facing stones have fallen.
The door is about 15 ft from the ground + I cd see vaulted +
plastered stair (?) inside it. Possibly a room, below the
door was a vaulted niche. I cd hear or see nothing
of Kiepert's Mazar of Sultan 'Abdullah, but there is a
small Muzar of Sultan Selim between Neshaba +
Kal'at Ja'bar, nearer the latter, in the plain. It was
rebuilt by Jemil Pasha + contains nothing old. The towers
of Abu Herera stood up on the opposite side of the river
a little above us. So to Kal'at Ja'bar where I lunched. It
is a very fine place in a chalk rock which is breaking
away. Mostly of brick with delightful brick string courses
+ decoration diamonds of open work; some stone in
the entrance wall + one tower half of stone. The
entrance is by a long covered passage hewn in the rock.
There is a large vaulted hall inside the enceinte - a
mosque? - + a good large building of many rooms all
of brick + variously vaulted. I noticed barrel vaults
carried up in
curves
lengthways - no doubt uncentered
- + only the top of the curve set in voussoirs. Also some
half lengthways + half longways with Byz. vaulting.

In the centre is a fair brick minaret with an inscription
round the top which I make out to be Maimun
( )
I hope this is so but I rather doubt whether in his time
the letters wd not have been Cufic? Beyond it a
vaulted cistern. On the NW side the hill is not very
steep + there are 2 rings of brick towers. On the
SE side it is precipitous+ there is little or no
fortification. Below the top on the level of the entrance
of the vaulted passage there is a large brick passage
chamber built against the face of the cliff. We left at
3 + at 3.30 rode under a Tell called S Chahf ez
Zaqq said to have ruins on it. At 3.45 we got to
the tents of Sheikh Hamri + found the mules
arrived but not camped. Fattuh, Hajj M., Selim
had gone off for tibu + corn + had not yet come.
So we pitched tents before the delighted gaze of the
tribe + Fattuh came in loaded with tibu. Then
I went to the Sheikh's tent for coffee. He is a
very cheerful talkative old man, full of gossip
of Nejd + elsewhere, uncle to Mabruk. Mark
Sykes was here for 2 days + went to Khirbet

Hadhe
. Hamri: "Freedom! There can't be freedom under
Islam. Shall I take wives contrary to the law of Islam
+ call it Freedom?" Very hot today; a long hard day.
I reckon it was 73/4 hours for the animals, but they went slowly.
Friday Feb 26. Dense fog. Went up onto Chahf ez Zaqq but there
are precious little remains on it. Off at 7.15. At 8.10 the path goes
behind the hill of Maharīz where there are vestiges of ruins (I believe)
