but I did not seem them in the fog. Soon after the road went quite
close to the river + at 9 we came to some caves. The place is
called Kdirān (Kiepert calls it Ghiran). We turned inwards
again; at 9.30 the fog lifted + showed an immense grass
plain, quite flat + very dull. It is the camping ground of the
'Anazeh in the summer. Camels of the Weldeh on it. I found
in the rocky ground a lovely small iris growing on a short stalk
out of narrow glaucous leaves. It was grey with a bold yellow
stripe down the inside of the outer leaves. At 10.55 we came to
Billaneh by the river. You see it from a long way off because
it is a ziarah + marked by great branches + trees stuck
into the ground by the graves. Fragments of the marble columns
of the temple that once stood there also mark the modern
tombs. The site very fine; the Euphrates comes down

to it fan shaped through many channels gather itself
up, broad + deep, into a single stream + sweeps under
the temple + beyond it round a wide bend. The Karakol
marked in Kiepert is old + ruined. The new one is a
little higher up the river. We left Billaneh at 11.10 +
rode till 11.35 through thickets of Tarfa, saghl (a
Arabic text
Arabic text
thorny bush just coming into leaf) + alga (blackberry)
under a low ridge of hills called Billaneh also. We
lunched by the river under the thorn bushes, very delightful
+ hot. Left here at 12.30 + shortly after saw +
caught up the baggage. All the way along the river
the Tarfa grows + sometimes into quite respectable
bushes. But the Arabs cut it for fuel + the cattle
+ horses eat it. At 3 Tell 'Abd 'Ali where there has
been building, but no stones are left only little
mounds. The baggage came in 10 min. later having
marched 71/2 hours. We are camped very far from the
river. There are 2 tents of the Afadh about 1/2 a mile
off + we sent one of the Arabs with a girbeh to
bring us water. He did not return till after 6.30
but the muleteers brought up some in our pail

when they went down to water the horses. Wonderful clear
sunset. A cloudless sky with a half moon. Temp. 47o at
7 o'clock. Barom. rising. We can see from the tell the hills
behind Raqqa. A very loud owl like a boy crying to sheep.
Sat Feb 27. Left Tell 'Abd 'Ali at 7.15 + at 8.5 got to
Haragla where I stayed till 8.45 + made a rough plan.
We got to Rakka at 10 + I rode straight off round the
town. First to the Baghdad gate which has an interesting
niched façade + inside there has been a dome set on
pendentives. Then to the Ziaret Sultan Waïs al Karani
over the door of which there is a piece of marble with
the following inscrip:
Arabic text
Arabic text
in the graveyard are numbers of marble columns +
built into the wall is something that looks very like a
small marble double column. The marble columns
must I think be antique. I saw 2 caps, one very
rough, one with the remains of acanthus. The dome
of the ziaret was set on squinches. Then to a tall
tower that stands in the inside of a large rectangular
space which was I think walled. It is called

El Amariyyeh (a decorated stringcourse of brick at top) + is reported to have been built by Abu Ja'far
al Barmek. It is square + of brick. At spaces up its
length there has been a layer of wood which has rotted
away + left a space. The base is of stone. I rather
think this town is supposed to have been built by
Ibn 'Ukab - at least an old man told me the
Boi (which Fattuh says is ) is attributed to him.
All the ground was covered with fragments of pottery.
So back to the walled city passing by the much
ruined Ziarah of Yahya el Garib Abu Ja'far Sheikh Salih. The dome was
also on squinches. Just inside the wall were
remains of a large building with plaster decorations.
One of the domes I cd photograph; the other was
too dark (it was very small); it was set on corbels
partly of brick partly of wood.
wooden beam. Then
to the great mosque which in the afternoon I began
to measure. The round minaret here is called El
'Alawiyyeh. The outer wall is of unburnt brick
like the walls of the town. So back to lunch.
Selim, the Liquorice agent came to see me + I
went to his house where I saw some pots - not

very good ones. I have engaged a Weldeh Arab called
Khalaf el Alayan, strongly recommended by M.
Sykes to come with me to Der. The road is quite
safe since I. Pasha's death. So back to the
mosque to measure - temp 70o in my tent at noon.
The big inscrip. in the mosque lacks 3 stones - I
saw 3 fragments built into 2 of the houses of the
town - Cufic

Also a most beautiful marble slab with a decorated
Cufic inscrip. which I photographed.
The dome of the little ziareh in the mosque is on squinches
or rather on niches
Sundat Feb 28. Rained all day. I divided my time between
buying £43 worth of Rakka ware + planning the mosque. The
bargaining for the pots was all done under the auspices of
Selim the agent for Forbes here who has been most obliging.
Cold + boring day nevertheless.
Monday March 1 Some trouble from Aleppo from whence had

come a telegram saying I was not to go through the Jezireh
but from Nakta to Nukta in the Shamiyyeh. I told them
to telegraph back that this was not my intention but they
did not send the telegram till the night, consequently there
was no answer this morning. I announced that I was
going with Khalaf + 'Abdullah, a man of Selim's, +
they gave me 2 soldiers without more ado. || Went to
the mosque + took some photographs. There has been
a double arcade all round the enclosure. The Circassians
or others have dug deep down + carried off all
the bricks. So of at 8.15 + caught up the baggage in
a few minutes. Got to Rakkat es Samra at 9.25 - I
suppose it is Rafika - a large area where there
has been building. I think Kiepert is wrong in placing
Tell
Zidan
on the W side of the Belikh. It is just on
the other side, on the rising ground to the E of the
river + I cd not visit it because of the river swamps
between me + it. Rakkat el Hamra is nearer to
the Euphrates - I did not go there. The Belikh is
all drawn off in channels to water the crops here
+ the river itself is a tiny brook which we

crossed by a brushwood bridge at 10.15. Here we waited a
few minutes for the animals + then Khalaf, Jusef, one of
my soldiers, Kiamil (a Circassian arrived but 3 years
ago with the other Muhajjerin at Rakka) rode off to
Jebel Munakhir. At 12.50 we reached a small outlying
Tell called Al Kecheret at Milha + stayed til 1.15 to
lunch. Jebel Munakhir is a volcano + the lava stretches
for some distance round it, broken stones + lava
dust. But the Tell is not volcanic; it is formed
of a block of white rock which lies above ground on top
of the tell. On the highest point remains of masonry
- a small tower? A few minutes brought us to the
foot of the mt up which Khalaf + I climbed only
to find that the one visible ruin was on the other
side of the crater. There were charming pale blue
iris verging to white with a yellow dash on the outer
petals. So we sent the horses round + crossed the
crater + climbed the other
first.
The building was
nothing but a ziareh - of a son of 'Abdul Kadir
of Baghdad said Khalaf. Splendid view. Kiepert is
rather wild here. His Tell Zedal is I think my Tell

Al Kechereh. The mt is called indifferently Jebel Munkhar
+ J. Manakhir, the second being obviously the plural of
the first. What Sachan calls Tell Menakhir is probably
the Ziareh. He does not mark Jebel Manakhar as
Sharki which lies about 3 miles E of J. Manakhir
al Gharbi. His Tulaba is probably the Jebel 'Ukula
which we saw on the horizon a little E of N. All this
country is 'Anazeh + we saw some of their tents. A
Jebel Baida is reported between J. Manakhir +
J. 'Abdul Aziz. Just below the mt were the tents of
Sheikh Dib el Hajju, of the Afadh where we spent
an hour from 2.15 - 3.15 drinking coffee. At 4.10 we
got down to a large encampment nearish the river
- the place is called Kubur ej Jebel - Kiepert does
not mark it nor is it any thing but a name. Here
Khalaf expected to find our tents but they had
wisely gone on another hour + camped in a
beautiful site on some rising ground by the river.
The Arabs call the place Mēda. Just beyond a
ruined site is reported called Khirbet Hadāwi.
The ruins of Tell Sha'ir are said to be 2 hours

from Abu Sa'id. In the low ground in the wide bend
of the river between Kubur ej Jebel + our camp we
crossed a space ringed round with a deep ditch -
for irrigation? I did not however go down it to see if it
led to the Euphrates. We got into camp at 5.30, a long
day but not tiring. Delicious weather. Khalaf announced
cheerfully that he was Gom with the Baqqara but
he intends nevertheless to camp by their tents so it can't
be bad. The baggage marched 71/2 hours.
Tuesday March 2. || Khalaf tried to make me promise him last night
£T4 for the journey to Der + as I refused to advance on the 6 mej.
agreed on, he came this morning + said his mare was lame. So he
went back to Rakka, at a gallop, + I took an Arab called 'Ali
from some tents near. All this delayed us + we did not set off till
7.45, 'Ali, Jusef, Ma'lul + I. || At 7.50 we passed a bit of rising
grass by the river called Khirbet Hadāwi - no visible ruins.
At 8.5 Khirbet ed Dukkiyyeh, ditto. At 8.25 we were at Jedede
where 'Ali said there were no ruins + at 8.45 at Abu Said Shair
where there is a Mazar of the 'Anazeh with tombs round it on
which are some fragments of columns + a great number of big
black basalt mills (?). From here we turned in land +

rode on the grass plains. We found some tents of the 'Anazeh
where I stopped + greeted the tribe. One with a long spear came
out + rode with us. "Lady" said he at the top of his
voice "my mare is ill; it is her intelligence, her intelligence
is sick. When you try to shoe her she escapes." We got to
Tell esh Sha'ir at 11.25 + stayed till 12.10. There were a few
stones on it dug out + set up one on the other, but I do not
think there had ever been a village, not that though the Tell could have
been artificial. But the stones part of a landmark. But there
is nowhere any trace of water storage or conduits + my
impression is that this bit of the desert has always been desert.
A few shepherds of the 'Anazeh joined us + finished up our
lunch. I saw Jebel Baida a little east of N on the horizon.
They said that J. 'Abd ul Aziz lay behind it. Some way
off to the E there are 5 or 6 Jubbs beneath a Tell called J. 'Ukula. More
to the W there is water at Abu Tata. So we rode back +
got down to the river at 3 + to our tents pitched by an
Afadh camp at 3/30 - on a tell which marks the
boundary with the Kaza of Der. The big Afadh Sheikh
of these parts is called Ajil el Hamry. The Desert is
beginning to be scented with jasūm which is just growing.

I had a long talk about the Const. with Ma'lul who is very
intelligent + the best informed soldier I ever had. He comes
from Kars + is a Turk - emigrated when the Russians took it.
He thinks it will be all right as to having Xians in the army
if there is not Khiana - disloyalty - a remark that goes
far. He wishes we wd send a Mafattish
(ruscer)
into
every vilayet. All the Effendis are corrupt + oppressors; when,
says he, one of these is sent as a deputy to C'ple his work
will not be good. But he places much confidence in the
Jeunes Turcs. Nearly everybody is for the Dastur. He cd live
on his pay if he only got it; at present he is owed 24
months' pay. The govt gives them clothes once a year but
these never reach soldiers in distant parts like Rakka
- they are eaten by the soldiers of Aleppo or by the officers -
+ he had had to buy his own. As yet there has been no change
for the better. The Effendis don't like the Dastur; they fear
Hurriyyeh + Hakm. Selim told me nearly everyone in
Rakka has a vote + casts it. As yet complete anarchy reigns
everywhere. Ma'lul + others have all heard that the king
is going to C'ple + all hope he will. He sang the praises of
Anatolia + said the Turks understood govt. + look all this
constitution was from them. But the Arabs not.

Wed March 3. Set off baggage + all at 7.15. Grey at first but the sun
came out after 2 hours; yesterday it was sunny + bitter cold. At
8.15 we came to Hneida where there has been a large town. Pottery
like that at Tell Sha'ir (it is sometimes called Jubb Sha'ir
+ there used to be Jubbs there which are now filled up - there
are a good many Jubbs scattered through the desert) a broken
sarcophagus, squared stones, burnt brick walls etc. At 9 we passed
another low mound strewn with pottery. At 9.35 we got to
Abu 'Alij, a wide stretch of ruined foundations on a high
bit of ground over the river. Below it is an ancient bed
of the Euphrates - a splendid site. We passed down + had just
crossed the Wadi Mālik when a soldier from Rakka overtook
us with a telegram from Catoni saying the Vali forbade
my travelling by the Jezireh on account of the danger. And
the Kaimakam had ordered that if I did not return my
soldiers were to come back. So I sent them back with
regret + we went on alone. The river here flows in a deep +
narrow channel between hills, very beautiful. At 11.50
we were opposite Halebiyyeh, a splendid stone fortress
like a triangle, the top being the castle + the towered
walls coming down fan shaped to the river. At

the SE angle there had been a bridge. At 12.10 we got to
Zelebiyyeh where I lunched till 12.35. It is a fortress like
Halebiyyeh, a towered wall (the towers square) enclosing
an oblong place over a steep high bank above the river
- the river side is not walled. A gate between two towers
leads into it. One the inside there is an arched niche
on either side of the gate. The masonry is of big blocks but
a good deal of mortar + rubble is used between the
faced sides. Below, upstream, are ruins of a town.
The road then left the Euphrates, passed over a hill +
down across a long bend. In the middle of this we saw
Tibuch on the other side. At 1.45 there was a mound with
foundations on it. At 2.10 we got to El Hied Kubbar
where there is a Ziarah; then we crossed another wide
bend + saw far off, on the other side of a hill
that came down to the Euphrates Kashla el Mungara.
We got there at 3.15, crossing over the hill, on the top
of which is Umm Reqeba. The Kashla has only been
built 10 years + is already falling into decay. It is
occupied by 8 soldiers, 4 or 5 of whom were
present + received us with joy. No Baqqara tents

anywhere near. The Baqqara are said to be rogues +
thieves. They were friends of Ibrahim Pasha's + are Gom
with the 'Anazeh. We camped in a beautiful grassy place
under the Kashla walls + above the Euphrates. After tea
I went up + inspected Umm Reqeba. To the E there is
a vast four square enclosure of which the wall is quite
distinct. To the W on the tell below the tombs (where
we saw columns + mills) there is a bit of circular
brick wall + a white mosaic pavement. Ma'lul
gave me a long account of the way the sheep tax is
levied. The govt. sends a man to levy it from a sheikh
- say 2000 ps (the tax on each sheep is 4 ps). He levies
4000 + gives the govt 1800. Another man has to be sent
to get the 200 ps. The sheikh levies another 1000 + gives
150| + so it goes on. As for the tax on zara', the owner
gives the govt. official a bribe + he estimates the
produce at less than 1/2 of its real amount. All the
laws between Rakka + Der (Shammiyyeh) last year only produced
£T800 + the sheep tax in the Jezireh £T2000. The
Sheikhs greatly oppress the Arabs under them. They
levy a large tax on every tent + if the fellahin

complain to the govt. the Sheikh levies war on them +
kills them + they have no protection. An Arab was riding with
us loudly echoed his approval of this description.
Thurs. March 4 Made a rough plan of Umm Reqeba in

there is a ditch
all round
outside the wall.
water course about

Old bed of Euphrates, the river
has corroded away the whole mound here
+ all trace of the well.
There was a piercing cold
wind but a bright sun.
Salih Oubashi, an old
one eyed soldier, served
as an escort, so that
we did not after all
arrive at Der un-
accredited. We had a
6 hours' ride, quite
dull, the road cutting
across all the loops
of the Euphrates, so that
I saw none of the
100 paces wide
places marked on the map - but I did not want to much.
About an hour outside Der there was rude water wheels
in the river irrigating small patches of corn now tall
+ green. We camped near the unfinished one (it has
